content.name: str
content.title: String
content.details:
A sequence of Unicode codepoints.

You can iterate over the grapheme clusters of the string using a for loop. Grapheme clusters are basically characters but keep together things that belong together, e.g. multiple codepoints that together form a flag emoji. Strings can be added with the + operator, joined together and multiplied with integers.

Typst provides utility methods for string manipulation. Many of these methods (e.g., split, trim and replace) operate on patterns: A pattern can be either a string or a regular expression. This makes the methods quite versatile.

All lengths and indices are expressed in terms of UTF-8 bytes. Indices are zero-based and negative indices wrap around to the end of the string.

You can convert a value to a string with this type's constructor.

Example

#"hello world!" \
#"\"hello\n  world\"!" \
#"1 2 3".split() \
#"1,2;3".split(regex("[,;]")) \
#(regex("\d+") in "ten euros") \
#(regex("\d+") in "10 euros")

Escape sequences

Just like in markup, you can escape a few symbols in strings:

  • \\ for a backslash
  • \" for a quote
  • \n for a newline
  • \r for a carriage return
  • \t for a tab
  • \u{1f600} for a hexadecimal Unicode escape sequence

constructor.name: str
constructor.title: Construct
constructor.oneliner: Converts a value to a string.
constructor.details:
Converts a value to a string.

  • Integers are formatted in base 10. This can be overridden with the optional base parameter.
  • Floats are formatted in base 10 and never in exponential notation.
  • Negative integers and floats are formatted with the Unicode minus sign ("−" U+2212) instead of the ASCII minus sign ("-" U+002D).
  • From labels the name is extracted.
  • Bytes are decoded as UTF-8.

If you wish to convert from and to Unicode code points, see the to-unicode and from-unicode functions.
constructor.example:
#str(10) \
#str(4000, base: 16) \
#str(2.7) \
#str(1e8) \
#str(<intro>)

params.name: value
params.details: The value that should be converted to a string.

params.name: base
params.details: The base (radix) to display integers in, between 2 and 36.

scope.name: len
scope.title: Length
scope.oneliner: The length of the string in UTF-8 encoded bytes.
scope.details: The length of the string in UTF-8 encoded bytes.

scope.name: first
scope.title: First
scope.oneliner: Extracts the first grapheme cluster of the string.
scope.details: Extracts the first grapheme cluster of the string. Fails with an error if the string is empty.

scope.name: last
scope.title: Last
scope.oneliner: Extracts the last grapheme cluster of the string.
scope.details: Extracts the last grapheme cluster of the string. Fails with an error if the string is empty.

scope.name: at
scope.title: At
scope.oneliner: Extracts the first grapheme cluster after the specified index. Returns
scope.details: Extracts the first grapheme cluster after the specified index. Returns the default value if the index is out of bounds or fails with an error if no default value was specified.

params.name: index
params.details: The byte index. If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: default
params.details: A default value to return if the index is out of bounds.

scope.name: slice
scope.title: Slice
scope.oneliner: Extracts a substring of the string.
scope.details: Extracts a substring of the string. Fails with an error if the start or end index is out of bounds.

params.name: start
params.details: The start byte index (inclusive). If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: end
params.details: The end byte index (exclusive). If omitted, the whole slice until the end of the string is extracted. If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: count
params.details: The number of bytes to extract. This is equivalent to passing start + count as the end position. Mutually exclusive with end.

scope.name: clusters
scope.title: Clusters
scope.oneliner: Returns the grapheme clusters of the string as an array of substrings.
scope.details: Returns the grapheme clusters of the string as an array of substrings.

scope.name: codepoints
scope.title: Codepoints
scope.oneliner: Returns the Unicode codepoints of the string as an array of substrings.
scope.details: Returns the Unicode codepoints of the string as an array of substrings.

scope.name: to-unicode
scope.title: To Unicode
scope.oneliner: Converts a character into its corresponding code point.
scope.details: Converts a character into its corresponding code point.
scope.example:
#"a".to-unicode() \
#("a\u{0300}"
   .codepoints()
   .map(str.to-unicode))

params.name: character
params.details: The character that should be converted.

scope.name: from-unicode
scope.title: From Unicode
scope.oneliner: Converts a unicode code point into its corresponding string.
scope.details: Converts a unicode code point into its corresponding string.
scope.example: #str.from-unicode(97)

params.name: value
params.details: The code point that should be converted.

scope.name: contains
scope.title: Contains
scope.oneliner: Whether the string contains the specified pattern.
scope.details:
Whether the string contains the specified pattern.

This method also has dedicated syntax: You can write "bc" in "abcd" instead of "abcd".contains("bc").

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for.

scope.name: starts-with
scope.title: Starts With
scope.oneliner: Whether the string starts with the specified pattern.
scope.details: Whether the string starts with the specified pattern.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern the string might start with.

scope.name: ends-with
scope.title: Ends With
scope.oneliner: Whether the string ends with the specified pattern.
scope.details: Whether the string ends with the specified pattern.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern the string might end with.

scope.name: find
scope.title: Find
scope.oneliner: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns the first
scope.details: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns the first match as a string or none if there is no match.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for.

scope.name: position
scope.title: Position
scope.oneliner: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns the index
scope.details: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns the index of the first match as an integer or none if there is no match.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for.

scope.name: match
scope.title: Match
scope.oneliner: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns a
scope.details:
Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns a dictionary with details about the first match or none if there is no match.

The returned dictionary has the following keys:

  • start: The start offset of the match
  • end: The end offset of the match
  • text: The text that matched.
  • captures: An array containing a string for each matched capturing group. The first item of the array contains the first matched capturing, not the whole match! This is empty unless the pattern was a regex with capturing groups.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for.

scope.name: matches
scope.title: Matches
scope.oneliner: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns an array of
scope.details: Searches for the specified pattern in the string and returns an array of dictionaries with details about all matches. For details about the returned dictionaries, see above.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for.

scope.name: replace
scope.title: Replace
scope.oneliner: Replace at most `count` occurrences of the given pattern with a
scope.details: Replace at most count occurrences of the given pattern with a replacement string or function (beginning from the start). If no count is given, all occurrences are replaced.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for.

params.name: replacement
params.details: The string to replace the matches with or a function that gets a dictionary for each match and can return individual replacement strings.

params.name: count
params.details: If given, only the first count matches of the pattern are placed.

scope.name: trim
scope.title: Trim
scope.oneliner: Removes matches of a pattern from one or both sides of the string, once or
scope.details: Removes matches of a pattern from one or both sides of the string, once or repeatedly and returns the resulting string.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to search for. If none, trims white spaces.

params.name: at
params.details: Can be start or end to only trim the start or end of the string. If omitted, both sides are trimmed.

params.name: repeat
params.details: Whether to repeatedly removes matches of the pattern or just once. Defaults to true.

scope.name: split
scope.title: Split
scope.oneliner: Splits a string at matches of a specified pattern and returns an array
scope.details:
Splits a string at matches of a specified pattern and returns an array of the resulting parts.

When the empty string is used as a separator, it separates every character (i.e., Unicode code point) in the string, along with the beginning and end of the string. In practice, this means that the resulting list of parts will contain the empty string at the start and end of the list.

params.name: pattern
params.details: The pattern to split at. Defaults to whitespace.

scope.name: rev
scope.title: Reverse
scope.oneliner: Reverse the string.
scope.details: Reverse the string.
